awd_titl_txt: TC: Small: Collaborative Research: Towards a Formal Framework for Analyzing and Implementing Secure Routing Protocols
awd_abstract_narration:
Today?s Internet runs Border Gateway Protocol (BGP), a complex inter-domain routing protocol. Over the past few years, there has been a growing consensus on the complexity and fragility of BGP routing. In addition to the problems of route oscillation and slow convergence, BGP has been shown to be susceptible to malicious attacks. Despite the wide range of proposed solutions to BGP's security vulnerabilities, there is currently a lack of a set of common tools for researchers to analyze, compare, and contrast the effectiveness of various schemes.

The goal of this project is to develop a unifying framework towards the design, analysis and implementation of provably secure Internet routing protocols. The first part of the project explores the use of Secure Network Datalog (SeNDlog), a declarative networking language for encoding secure Internet routing protocols.  Language extensions to SeNDLog will be explored, in order to address practical deployments issues at Internet-scale, and facilitate formal analysis of a range of secure routing protocols. These extensions include customizable authentication, goal-oriented evaluation, key distribution and management, and modeling of adversaries. The second part of this project aims to identify security properties of Internet routing protocols, and formally specify them logically in terms of protocol execution traces. The third part of this project aims to design and implement a formal analysis methodology towards verifying SeNDlog programs for desired security properties specified in logic.

In terms of broader impact, this project will result a cleaner foundation towards the analysis and development of trustworthy routing protocols.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project is to develop a unifying framework towards the design, analysis and implementation of provably secure Internet routing protocols. This project carried out the following research activities, namely (1) the development of the SANDLog (Secure and Authenticated Network Datalog) language for implementing secure network protocols, (2) a sound logic for SANDlog and Coq-based proof techniques to verify invariant properties in an adversarial environment, (3) combined use of static analysis and Z3 for implementing provably correct Software-Defined Networking (SDN) programs, (4) techniques to dynamically compress distributed provenance stored at scale for the purpose of network forensics. In addition to the RapidNet declarative networking platform targeted at control plane programming, the project has also led to the formal verification of OPT, a lightweight scalable, and secure protocols for source authentication and path validation and the development of MTor anonymous communications systems, and the Scanalytics declarative traffic analytics platform for the data plane.

 In terms of broader impact, this project results in software engineering and formal verification techniques that resulted a cleaner foundation towards the analysis and development of trustworthy routing protocols. In terms of intellectual impact, this research project resulted in the combined use of programming languages, database technologies, and formal methods in the area of network security. In network security, there is still a significant gap in formal analysis and actual implementations. This project has led to new scientific advancements and tools development to help bridge the gap, hence enabling us to build provably secure distributed systems.

The research work has also led to advancing research in two other communities. In programming languages and formal methods domain, the research has found new application domains for formal proof techniques, and an improved understanding on the combined use of static and runtime analysis. In the database community, the research has led to enhancements of existing data provenance models to distributed settings in networks, and use of high performance data processing techniques to detect security anomalies in networks.

In terms of education impact, this project has led to the development of new graduate level courses on Rigorous Internet Protocol Engineering and Software Defined Data Centers. Two doctoral Ph.D. dissertations emerged from this grant, and several masters students and undergrads receive research training while working on this grant.
